awd_titl_txt: Non-Innocent Main Group Centers for Targeted Multi-Electron Transformations
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalysts are species that improve the speed, the energy consumption, and/or the efficiency of chemical reactions; they are essential for industrial chemistry and for biological processes. The design of new catalysts is an important area of research as there is continual need for them in order to develop more efficient chemical processes. A special class of catalysts are those that can facilitate a flow of electrons to perform multi-electron chemical transformations. Professor Gabriel Menard, Chemistry Department, University of California - Santa Barbara, is supported by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division to develop new catalysts for multi-electronic processes. These catalysts are based on inexpensive, abundant metals that are able to transfer electrons to and activate a non-metal center. This is nearly opposite the usual design in which the electron transfer goes from a non-metal to activate a metal center. These new catalysts open new processes to everyday goods and utilize common, inexpensive starting materials. Students from underrepresented groups are engaged in this research and Professor Menard seeks to increase broader scientific literacy by hosting a free, monthly "Science Pub Night" event, where scientists present their research to the public in an open and accessible way.

This project investigates how tethering multi-metallic redox-active platforms to group 13 or group 15 centers facilitate multi-electron transformations at the main-group site. A goal is to develop main-group catalysts for multi-electron processes. By coordinating vanadium to various ligands, complexes with a variety of redox properties are obtained. These are attached to group 13 or 15 centers to generate species that contain up to three vanadium moieties attached to a main-group atom. The compounds are characterized by the usual chemical and spectroscopic techniques, with particular attention being paid to the electrochemical and magnetic properties. The presence of several vanadium atoms provides the ability for cooperative, multi-electron redox chemistry at the main group unit. This reactivity is probed in atom or group transfer chemistry and for the activation of water, ammonia, and hydrogen.  This research provides excellent training to undergraduate and graduate students in the synthesis and characterization of typically air sensitive molecules. This prepares them for careers in academia, industry, or national laboratories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to investigate the synthesis of so-called “redox non-innocent” main group centers tethered to encapsulated metal electron reservoirs and their reactivity with small molecules. We specifically aimed to synthesize main group/multi-metallic architectures and explore their reactivity with atom/group transfer reagents and small molecules. Vanadium was primarily chosen as the redox active center combined with Group 13 or Group 15 main group centers. The goal was to probe the reactivity of these new “non-innocent” main group compounds in multi-electron atom or group transfer chemistry, and small molecule activation and functionalization.

Exploring group 13 congeners, we synthesized complexes of the general formula, X3V=N-B(C6F5)2 (X = NPh2 or X3 = N(CH2CH2N(C6F5))3) which displayed interesting 1 electron chemistry involving C–H bond activation, as well as frustrated Lewis pair type reactivity. As part of this work, we also observed that the B center in this complex would display typical Lewis acidic BIII behavior when the neighboring V center was in the +5 oxidation state, but would display reactivity reminiscent of a “hidden” boron radical (BII) when in the VIV oxidation state through resonance of the single electron along the V–N–B manifold. We investigated how the combined Lewis acidity at B and redox at the VIV/V center could be used to promote significant coordination-induced bond weakening (CIBW) at a series of B-coordinated E–H donors. Substantial decreases in E–H bond dissociation free energies were observed upon substrate coordination, enabling subsequent facile proton-coupled electron transfer. We have also made significant progress in synthesizing bi- and tri-metallic species with Al, with the general formula (N(CH2CH2N(C6F5))3)V=N)nAlX3-n (X = Cl, Br, I; n = 2, 3). Our goals here are to target 2 and 3 electron transformations.

In addition to the general V-based platforms, we have expanded our metal-main group structures to include Fe. Using similar design principles, we generated SO2R-tethered Fe complexes, which underwent a sequence of spontaneous C-H activation and C-C bond forming steps.

Lastly, we have more recently shifted our previous attention on our previous (Ph2N)3V=N-POAr2 complexes by specifically swapping out the redox-active V moiety for ortho-carborane redox-active centers. This forms the basis of our ongoing NSF-sponsored work investigating CIBW of energy important molecules.

The impacts of this funding are broad. Six graduate students participated in this research with many gaining important scientific research skills, as well as professional development opportunities despite the ongoing challenges of the pandemic. In addition, this research has advanced fundamental understandings in main group/metal cooperative reactivity and multi-electron transformations. Moreover, the potential discoveries outlined here may have significant impacts on the renewable energy sector and on society as we transition away from fossil fuels.


Last Modified: 10/24/2022
Modified by: Gabriel Menard
